Well, that was pretty painless. Welcome to my blog, although I'm probably only talking to myself. Which is fine, as this blog is intended to serve as a memory, a history of thoughts to clue me in to the subtleties and nuances of the past that my brain tends to forget.

Leo Laporte. You gotta love the guy. He was great on Tech TV. Its a shame that Comcast bought them out and cancelled half the shows. I'm just happy The Screensavers is still on. It better be at the same time (7PM EST). It will be interesting to see just how homogonized they will make such an off-the-cuff, honest TV show. urlLink The Laporte Report

I don't know if this guys a genius or a loser, but no one can deny his effort: A detailed map of the town of Springfield, as interpreted though 15 seasons of Simpsons episodes. This is one guy I'd like on my team when playing The Simpsons Trivia Game (of which I can't seem to answer one question right). Yes... I have the Simpsons trivia game. I guess we're both losers.... urlLink Guide to Springfield USA

This LCD monitor seems to be as perfect as you can get nowadays. 12ms response time, huge viewing angle, 3 year warranty. It even includes extra brackets for mounting right on the wall. Now to see if they have this in larger sizes with the same response time and maybe a higher native resolution... and widescreen. The search for the perfect monitor is one step closer. urlLink [Tweaknews.net] - SAMSUNG SYNCMASTER 172X LCD TFT MONITOR REVIEW -

I've been seriously considering making my next desktop a Mac (horror of horrors!). The jury is still out on that one, but this bit of news may just lean me closer to the Apple side of the court. "you want to use iMovie with your Sony DCR-DVD300, right? I hear (have not done this myself) that this is easily done by using Quicktime Pro to convert the .vob files from the DVD into .dv files, which can then be used in iMovie. Secondly, I will bet iMovie will soon support these camcorders." Story developing..... Here a thread regarding this issue. Doesn't look promising: urlLink MPEG-2 in iMovie

Here are some extremely cool and thought provoking art/furniture/clocks. I really want the colorwheel clock. But since its "designer" I'm sure they will charge a ridiculous amount of money for what boils down to a few bucks in plastic. urlLink MoCoLoco: Coulheur

Always wanted to easily create your own MP3 ringtones? I did! This program makes it easy: urlLink Xingtone Just pop your CD in, select the part of the song you want, and Xingtone uploads it and sends your phone an SMS with the link. Its 14.95 for the full version. But from what I see, it seems worth it. Especially when T-Mobile is selling MP3 ringtones for $1.99 each. Now I can finally make those Death Cab For Cutie ringtones I wanted. urlLink Engadget.com has a great article on how to create your own ringtones.

Ah ha! Just when the onslaught of stories about Dean using the internet to form a grassroots base had you believing only librals knew how to use the internet for politics, along comes a fellow blogger to prove otherwise. Leading the charge, Esoteric Diatribe has raised the call to arms to fellow conservative bloggers and managed to push www.johnkerry.com to number 1 on the search of the word "waffles" on google.com. Go ahead, try it yourself! urlLink Google: Waffles urlLink Esoteric * Diatribe And now to do my part: urlLink waffles

Heres an interesting blog about share houses in the Hamptons. Because I live in the backyard of the Hamptons, I have a peculiar interest in the whole Hamptons summer scene. It intrigues me the lengths people will go to meet/court and act like rich people. I really couldnt imagine driving 2-3 hours each way every weekend to live on the floor of a glorified frat house and call it a "vacation". urlLink JoonBlog New York: This Summer in the Hamptons - The Share House An anonymous commenter steered me to a great summer share house website, for all of those whom it floats thier boat: urlLink SummerShareHouse.com

I stumbled across this band urlLink COHEED AND CAMBRIA . The music is pretty interesting. Their vocals are a very 80's. Now that I think of it, the whole band is very 80's. I feel like its 1989 when I listen to them. Yet still they intrigue me.
urlLink This is a picture from our Honeymoon in Hawaii. Its a beach in Pi'ia. urlLink

urlLink This is the Sony "Ipod killer". Not very exciting. It has some cool ideas, but they don;t really seem to add anything to the device. The matrix of dots on the right of the screen are touch sensitive and allow you to "scroll" through menus and such. It also has a color screen on which you can view stored photos... another feature that won't sell any extra units. Its only available in Japan in the near future. urlLink

If your like me, your sick of the Michael Moore love-fest thats going on in the media right now. Thats why I thought I'd round up a good selection of links showing the discrepancies, lies and glaringly void facts of Fahrenheit 9/11. Enjoy! The author of Michael Moore is a Big Fat Stupid White Man runs this great site that contains the past and present verbal atrocities of Michael Moore. urlLink Moorelies.com - Michael Moore's Permanent Record This is a lengthy but VERY informative article that systematically destroys Michael Moore's "arguments" in Fahrenheit 9/11. Excellent counter material for that Buddy Holly glasses wearing elite we all know. urlLink Unfairenheit 9/11 - The lies of Michael Moore. By Christopher Hitchens This article sums up the movie into a short list of "facts" that Moore directly and indirectly shoves down your throat. urlLink Cliff notes version of Fahrenheit 911

urlLink So the Apple Developer Conference WWDC was today. Besides a bunch of cool developer stuff included in the intro of "Tiger",the new Mac OS X, the only hardware introduced was 3 new LCD displays in 20, 23 and 30 inch varieties. They are REAL nice... and REAL expensive. The 30 incher sports a native resolution of 2560x1600. The DVI standard doesnt support resolutions that high so they have to sell a special double video card made by NVidia for it. urlLink Apple - Cinema Displays urlLink

So lately you computers been running slow and doing wierd things? You might just be infested with spyware. But how do you get rid of something that you can't see? Anti-Spyware. Wired performed an evaluation of the leading anti-spyware software out there and came to some pretty interesting conclusions. The FREE software worked better than the $50 stuff at getting rid of the spyware. MUCH better. urlLink Wired News: An Arsenal to Combat Spyware

Microsoft submitted a patent that covers the transmission of power and communication signals through the body. This is a very interesting idea: have a bunch of small wearable devices on your body that can communicate and even power each other forming a personal area network (PAN). I'd like to see the working prototypes of this. I wouldn't want to be the product tester for that one. I wonder if they will now get royalties from the electric chair.. oh I mean electric "personal area network". urlLink Microsoft patents body power | CNET News.com

urlLink Clock Table urlLink This is one of the coolest clocks I've seen. Currently it's only a prototype, but I'm sure they will eventually sell it for some crazy amount of money to people like Bill Gates. urlLink Wristfashion has more cool clocks urlLink Clock Table Designers

The Olympic Torch comes to the city this weekend. Its one of those events that you wish you saw, but its really so non-eventfull that you'd never take the time to go down to one of the locations and actually see it. Never-the-less, the Gothamist has all the good links to the route info, etc. I just wonder how it gets from major location to major location. It was in LA like yesterday. Is it really the same flame? Do they keep it burning on an airplane? Does someone get to hold it in the airplane seat? That seems like cheating. urlLink Gothamist: Olympic Torch Relay in NYC on Saturday

This is a pretty nifty piece of code that can be added to a blog, or any website for that matter, that lists all the websites that refer to your page. Like a reverse google of sorts. urlLink Track referers to your site! Check your reciprocal links. Find links to your site. TrueFresco Referrer Feed. referrer tracking, website referrers, referrers
urlLink
urlLink

The horror! After hours of debates and police disputed arguments between environmentalists and US Open officials, the endangered piping plover nest in the 3rd hole sandtrap suddenly "disappeared". I'm not sure who's more pathetic, the environmentalists who cordoned off the area with police tape, the police who drove out on the fairway with their red lights flashing, or the US Open officials who deliberated for hours over whether a ball in the Plover sandtrap would incite a one stoke penalty or a free ball drop. The US Open has put up $500,000 reward for the arrest of the "perpetrator". As the police chief said, "Damned strange if you ask me". This stories worth a read. Pure Long Island East End ridiculousness. urlLink Dan's Papers - Read Dan's Papers

Who would have thought a blog on furniture could be so interesting!? Funfurde is just that. Its like a directory of all that is modern in funiture design. I think he's from NYC too, so many of the blogs cover stores located in the city. urlLink Funfurde

Engadget has this very cool quick guide on how to turn your PC into a Mac. Theres a bunch of programs out there that will skin and shade WinXP to look and feel just like Mac OS X. Gimicky but cool. urlLink Turn your PC into a Mac
Check out these really cool keychains. They have some really cool and simple metal designs. Google it for US distributors. urlLink Willkommen bei TROIKA - key-rings

Brandtsons new CD Send Us A Signal is set for a June 15th release. From what I've heard of it, its somewhat of a departure from thier previous releases... in a good way. Brandtsons last few releases were good, but stagnant. The last 3 releases could have all fit together into one big album. Send Us A Signal seems to be a breadth of fresh air to what was becoming a formulaic pattern of releases. Thier new home at The Militia Group is serving them well. Send Us A Signal will be available on iTunes. Something Deep Elm never came close to achieving with thier weak distribution. urlLink Brandtson.com

I wouldn't exactly call half of the CD's they sell there "punk", but they do have a really good and cheap selection of indie/punk/emo cd's to download. This fills the void between iTunes and Kazaa. urlLink downrip.com : punk mp3 store

urlLink Heres a bunch of pictures of an Extreme Makeover Home Edition house. I like the wall designs and colors. Maybe these will inspire Jess and I to come up with something for our apartment. The white is getting bland. urlLink
urlLink urlLink
urlLink urlLink

Heres some juicy info on Apples next iPod via AppleInsider.com. Seems the device will contain the to-be released Toshiba 60GB drive in time for September. Its rumored to have a 2 inch color screen and a previously rumored "enhanced" dock with video outs. Its also rumored to be using some sort of mini-OS to run everything. This could be very interesting. Theres a whole lot of hurdles Apple will have to get over to make this one work. I'm not so much excited about watching movies on a 2-inch screen, which seems a bit of a novelty to me. What I'm excited about is the ability to use this as some sort of portable Tivo... and the possiblity of combining PDA type functionality into the OS (something a bit more robust than the Notes feature of the current iPods). Theres also the "Home on the go" concept that Apples been tpying around with, but if that ever happens it will be a Mac OS thing only I'm sure. I wonder if they will reveal any of this at WWDC in June. urlLink AppleInsider | Sources: 4th generation iPod due this Fall

Thanks to Zac, I now have an XM Commander! Now for the installation. Should be REAL easy, but it ALWAYS seems real easy, and then 3 hours later you have harness wires cut and one of your fingers is bleeding. So check out the links below for some insight into installation of an XM Commander into a VW Jetta 1.8T urlLink VWvortex Forums: Terk XM commander + Monsoon DD + Enfig adapter urlLink Mor VWVortex XM Commander discussion

About a month ago I was driving on the LIE on a Sunday and a real exotic looking car flew by at around 80 MPH in the HOV lane. I've seen plenty of nice cars in the Hamptons (Bentleys, Rolls Royce, Ferraris, etc), but this was something I'd never seen before. I couldnt make out the emblem as it was going by, but I did notice the rear window curtains! Well I finally found out what it was.. a Maybach. HowStuffWorks.com has a great overview of some of it features, which include a refrigerator, reclining rear seats, a glass sunroof controlled by liquid crystal, V-12 540+ HP, and the list goes on. They go for $300,000 to $400,000 and only 1,000 are made a year. Now I just wonder who was in it.... urlLink How Maybachs Work urlLink Maybach USA

urlLink I'm now an uncle. Zac and Andrea had thier twins David and Jeanna today! For more pictures go to my fotopic gallery: urlLink http://chrismurphy.fotopic.net/c244250.html urlLink Update: Zac has more pictures here: urlLink http://garsik.blogspot.com/2004/07/there-here.html

A group calling themselves the Electronic Frontier Foundation is on a mission to keep digital recordings legal. As of July 1st, 2005, all digital TV receivers will have to use the new mandated broadcast "flag" that will make it impossible to record or time-shift TV broadcasts. The EFF wants people to buy off the self computer parts to build thier own TiVo like devices now, before the switch next year. Wired has the details and links below. urlLink Wired News: Group Warns DVRs Endangered

Engadget has a great tutorial on how to use your iPod as a universal remote. It involves recording the "sound" of the various buttons on your remotes and then playing them back through the iPod with a IR transmitter plugged into the headphone jack. While this may not end up being the most functional universal remote on the market, it makes up for that in geek factor alone. urlLink How-To Turn your iPod in to a Universal Infrared Remote Control - Engadget - www.engadget.com

Gather round Republican and Democrat boys and girls. Its story time. I came across this parable in the comments of the seanbonner.com post below. I'd give credit, but last time I checked i knew youknowthisemailisfake@yahoo.com is fake. A woman in a hot air balloon realized she was lost. She lowered altitude and spotted a man in a boat below. She shouted to him, "Excuse me, can you help me? I promised a friend I would meet him an hour ago, but I don't know where I am." The man consulted his portable GPS and replied, "You're in a hot air balloon approximately 30 feet above a ground elevation of 2346 feet above sea level. You are 31 degrees, 14.97 minutes north latitude and 100 degrees, 49.09 minutes west longitude." She rolled her eyes and said, "You must be a Republican." "I am," replied the man. "How did you know?" "Well," answered the balloonist, "everything you told me is technically correct, but I have no idea what to make of your information, and I'm still lost. Frankly, you've not been much help to me." The man smiled and responded, "You must be a Democrat." "I am," replied the balloonist. "How did you know?" "Well," said the man, "You don't know where you are or where you're going. You've risen to where you are due to a large quantity of hot air. You made a promise that you have no idea how to keep, and you expect ME to solve your problem. You're in EXACTLY the same position you were in before we met, but, somehow now, it's MY fault..."!

urlLink elitist Russell Simmons owns an apartment overlooking ground zero. Him and his "activist" friends thought they could change the world by putting posters saying, "No More Lies", "No More War" and peace signs in the loft. I have a different idea. :) Sean Bonner has the real pictures. urlLink http://www.seanbonner.com/blog/archives/000674.php#000674 urlLink

Poor Tivo. Thier Tivo On The Go feature which lets you transfer TV programs to your home computer, etc.. has been forever fought by the movie and TV industry from the beginning. The proposed service is already crippled by design to only allow transfers to registered devices, but that apparently isnt enough. The FCC is set to rule on this in a few weeks. urlLink Yahoo! News - TiVo's Plans Lead to Fight On Copyrights

Rich Lowry is my new hero. I heard Rush Limbaugh quote this article in the National Review Online on his show yesterday. I havn't heard the blind hatred of Bush explained in such consise, factual terms any better than Rich Lowry does in this article. I dare a libral to explain this away. I have reprinted it below: W.’s Double Binds Sometimes a political figure becomes so hated that he can't do anything right in the eyes of his enemies. President Bush has achieved this rare and exalted status. His critics are so blinded by animus that the internal consistency of their attacks on him no longer matters. For them, Bush is the double-bind president. If he stumbles over his words, he is an embarrassing idiot. If he manages to cut taxes or wage a war against Saddam Hussein with bipartisan support, he is a manipulative genius. If he hasn't been able to capture Osama bin Laden, he is endangering U.S. security. If he catches bin Laden, it is only a ploy to influence the elections. If he ignores U.N. resolutions, he is a dangerous unilateralist. If he takes U.N. resolutions on Iraq seriously, he is a dangerous unilateralist. If he doesn't get France to agree to his Iraq policy, he is ignoring important international actors. If he supports multiparty talks on North Korea, he is not doing enough to ignore important international actors. If he bombed Iraq, he should have bombed Saudi Arabia instead, and if he had bombed Saudi Arabia, he should have bombed Iran, and if he had bombed all three, he shouldn't have bombed anyone at all. If he imposes a U.S. occupation on Iraq, he is fomenting Iraqi resistance by making the United States seem an imperial power. If he ends the U.S. occupation, he is cutting and running. If he warns of a terror attack, he is playing alarmist politics. If he doesn't warn of a terror attack, he is dangerously asleep at the switch. If he says we're safer, he's lying, and if he doesn't say we're safer, he's implicitly admitting that he has failed in his core duty as commander in chief. If he adopts a doctrine of preemption, he is unacceptably remaking American national-security policy. If the United States suffers a terror attack on his watch, he should have preempted it. If he signs a far-reaching antiterror law, he is abridging civil liberties. If the United States suffers another terror attack on his watch, he should have had a more vigorous anti-terror law. Bush's economy hasn't created new jobs. If it has created new jobs, they aren't well-paying jobs. If they are well-paying jobs, there is still income inequality in America. If Bush opposes a prescription-drug benefit for the elderly, he's miserly. If he supports a prescription-drug benefit for the elderly, he's lining the pockets of the pharmaceutical companies. If he restrains government spending, he's heartless. If he supports government spending, he's bankrupting the nation and robbing from future generations. If he opposes campaign-finance reform, he's a tool of corporate interests. If he signs campaign-finance reform, he's abridging the First Amendment rights of Michael Moore (whose ads for Fahrenheit 9/11 might run afoul of the law). If he accuses John Kerry of flip-flopping, he is merely highlighting one of the Massachusetts senator's strengths — his nuance and thoughtfulness. If he flip-flops on nation-building or testifying before the 9/11 commission, he proves his own ill-intentions, cluelessness, or both. If he doesn't admit a mistake, he is bullheaded and detached from reality. If he admits a mistake, he is damning his own governance in shocking fashion. If he sticks with Dick Cheney, he is saddling himself with an unpopular vice president, giving Democrats who can't wait to run against Cheney a political advantage. If he drops Cheney, he is admitting that the Democratic attacks against his vice president have hit home, thus giving Democrats who have made those charges a political advantage. If he loses in November, the voice of the American people has spoken a devastating verdict on his presidency. If he wins, he stole the election. — Rich Lowry is author of Legacy: Paying the Price for the Clinton Years. urlLink Rich Lowry on George W. Bush & Election 2004 on National Review Online

urlLink Today Apple released the new iPod. Its 1mm, yes MILLImeter (woopdee doo), thinner than the previous generation and features a clickable scroll wheel very similar to the iPod mini. However, probably the most trumpeted feature by current iPod users will be the 12 hour battery life, up from 8. Other than that, theres a few tweaks to the user interface, such as the "Shuffle Songs" button on the main menu. This was sorely needed, as previously you had to go through multiple tiers of menus to get to it. I hope they release a firmware update for us older iPod users. Pricing has been "reduced" by 100 bucks for both the 20 and 40 GB models. I use quotes because they removed a bunch of accessories from the box. So its not as much of a price reduction as you might think. Check out urlLink http://www.apple.com for the goods. urlLink

Digital Design Museum has a great set of articles about Jonathan Ive's designs, the Industrial Designer behind pretty much all Apples products for the last 10 years. They have little blurbs about all the products he designed (iPod, iMac, PowerBook, etc..) explaing how and why they designed each the way they did. Its great when form and function combine, although it always seems to have the unfortunate byproduct of high prices. Worth a read. urlLink Jonathan Ive, Apple - Digital Design Museum

Check out this new public toilet "art piece". Its a toilet surrounded by 1 way mirrors, so from inside you can see out, but not vice-versa. Pretty eerie, but I don't know if I'd consider this "art". Pictures of the toilet from inside and out at urlLink Cool Hunting

urlLink OK, so the V1000 PC case from Lian Li is a complete rip-off of a PowerMac G5, but its a QUALITY rip-off. Machined aluminum all around with lockable wheels underneath and a compartmentalized interior that was engineered for the best flow of air. Even the PCI slot covers are aluminum. Its about time style has come to the PC world, even if it was inspired by Apple. urlLink PC Unleashed review: Lian Li V1000 urlLink Overclocker Cafe review: Lian Li V1000 urlLink Buy a V1000 urlLink Via Gizmodo urlLink

Sick of the same old T-shirts at the local mall? Sick of wearing corporate logos? What do you do when you've run out of bands to get T-Shirts for? Head-on over to threadless.com. They have tons of really cool and interesting shirts. Its an interactive T-Shirt community, where you can rate T-shirts and even submit your own designs! Suddenly I'm excited about buying T-shirts! urlLink Threadless T-Shirts!

Now that the self-righteous Michael Moore has publicly stated he supports free distribution of his latest movie, I just might take the opportunity to view his propaganda first hand. As long as he, or the Democratic Party don't get a cent, I encourage everyone to watch this movie and witness just how cook-fringe, hatred filled, lying Democrats see the world. BoingBoing has a great little tutorial on how to get it. urlLink Boing Boing: A Directory of Wonderful Things

PVR blog has a nice little roundup of a few reviews on TiVo vs. Windows Home Media Center. As was pretty clear to me from the get-go, TiVo comes out on top for ease of use, reliability and when it really comes down to it, price. Media Center wins on archival abilities, but that's about it. Basically, Media Center is for TV/film buffs and/or geeks who think they are too smart to pay $12.95 a month for a simple elegant solution and TiVo is for the rest of us. urlLink TiVo versus Media Center | PVRblog

urlLink Now this is a portable harddrive with style! The LaCie is a 20/40 GB bus powered hard drive shaped in magnesium to look just like a bar of silver. The firewire and USB 2.0 ports are even hidden behind a panel to complete the look. I'd say you best not leave one of these out unattended... and for 229.00 and 329.00 each, I'd say leave a real bar of silver out on your desk as a decoy, cause its probably much cheaper! I expect gold or platinum versions of these to show up in rap videos shortly. urlLink LaCie Data Bank urlLink Via Engadget urlLink

Ping Pong: Matrix Style. I may be a bit behind the curve on this one, but I just saw it for the first time this weekend. Looks like it was for a Japanese Gong Show. This is genius. Check out the video below: urlLink Swoj.com - Videos, Matrix Ping Pong

So it looks like the VIN system is running out of numbers. And it turns out that adding extra digits could potentially cost millions. The suggested solution will be decided in September, but it's looking like they may re-use old VIN #'s. This seems like a logistical nightmare to me. urlLink Too many cars, too few digits - 07/01/04 They have a nice diagram of the explantion of each digit of a VIN # at the bottom of the article. Pretty interesting.

For those of us who have yet to get a DVD Recorder, hold out just a bit longer. Analysts say the prices of DVD Recorder will fall 50% in the 2nd half of this year thanks to cheaper ASIC's and those good ole Taiwanese. First dual-layer burners, now this! This Christmas may just be the year of the DVD burner. urlLink PCWorld.com - DVD Recorder Prices Expected to Plunge

Well, I've been toying with the idea of transfering my home phone over to Vonage. I'm still a bit hesitant, but voice over IP has come a long way, so I hear. Heres some good sources of information for those who are in the same boat. urlLink Vonage.com urlLink The Official Vonage Forum urlLink The Official Unofficial Vonage Forum

I would consider this a moveon.org for the right. Redstate.org is a collection of blogs and discussion from republican bloggers. A great way to catch up on the side of the news you don't get from the mainstream media. urlLink Redstate.org

Metacritic is a cool website I stumbled upon that has reviews of films, games, music and DVD's. You may be saying "So what?..". What makes Metacrtic different, is that it compiles a list of reviews from professional reviewers around the internet and creates an average rating based upon these outside reviews. Think of it as a one stop shop of reviews. urlLink metacritic: Film Reviews, Game Reviews, Music Reviews, DVD Reviews
